Reports on implementation of Law Commission proposals
	After section 3 of the [Law Commissions Act 1965 (c.22)](/id/ukpga/1965/22?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") insert—
	“3AReports on implementation of Law Commission proposals
		As soon as practicable after the end of each reporting year, the LordChancellor must prepare a report on—
			the Law Commission proposals implemented (in whole or in part) during theyear;
			the Law Commission proposals that have not been implemented (in whole or inpart) as at the end of the year, including—
			plans for dealing with any of those proposals;
			any decision not to implement any of those proposals (in whole or in part)taken during the year and the reasons for the decision.
		The Lord Chancellor must lay the report before Parliament.
		The first reporting year is the year starting with the day on which section1 of the Law Commission Act 2009 comes into force; and the second reportingyear is the year after that and so on.
		If a decision not to implement a Law Commission proposal (in whole or inpart) is taken in a reporting year, subsection (1)(b) does not require areport for a later reporting year to deal with the proposal so far as it iscovered by that decision.
		If a decision not to implement a Law Commission proposal (in whole or inpart) has been taken before the first reporting year, subsection (1)(b) doesnot require any report to deal with the proposal so far as it is covered bythat decision.
		“Law Commission proposal” means—
			a proposal formulated by the Law Commission as mentioned in section3(1)(c);
			a proposal for consolidation or statute law revision for which a draft Billhas been prepared by the Law Commission as mentioned in section 3(1)(d).”
Protocol about the Law Commission’s work
	Before section 4 of the [Law Commissions Act 1965 (c.22)](/id/ukpga/1965/22?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") insert—
	“3BProtocol about the Law Commission’s work
		The Lord Chancellor and the Law Commission may agree for the purposes ofthis section a statement (a “protocol”) about the Law Commission’s work.
		The protocol may include (among other things) provision about—
			principles and methods to be applied in deciding the work to be carried outby the Law Commission and in the carrying out of that work;
			the assistance and information that Ministers of the Crown and the LawCommission are to give each other;
			the way in which Ministers of the Crown are to deal with the LawCommission’s proposals for reform, consolidation or statute law revision.
		The Lord Chancellor and the Law Commission must from time to time reviewthe protocol and may agree to revise it.
		The Lord Chancellor must lay the protocol (and any revision of it) beforeParliament.
		Ministers of the Crown and the Law Commission must have regard to theprotocol.”
Commencement and short title
	This Act comes into force at the end of the period of 2 months beginningwith the day on which it is passed.
	This Act may be cited as the Law Commission Act 2009.
